title: How to Make Slow Cooker Enchilada Sauce

methods.name: Preparing Basic Slow Cooker Enchilada Sauce

steps.headline: Cut the onions and remove the skins.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to cut 2 large onions in half. Use your fingers to peel away the skin, and set the onion pieces aside. Yellow onions work best for the enchilada sauce.

steps.headline: Slice the jalapenos and remove the seeds.
steps.description: Cut 4 jalapenos in half with a sharp knife. Use a spoon to carefully scrape out the seeds and discard them. Wash your hands immediately after handling the jalapenos. The capsaicin in the jalapenos can sting your eyes if you touch them without washing your hands. Some people experience burning in their skin after handling jalapenos, so you may prefer to wear protective gloves, such as latex or rubber, while you’re cutting them.

steps.headline: Mix all of the ingredients in the slow cooker.
steps.description: Once the onion and jalapenos are cut, place them in the slow cooker along with 4 cloves of garlic that have been peeled and smashed, ½ cup (64 g) of chili powder, 3 tablespoons (23 g) of cumin, 2 tablespoons (25 g) of sugar, 2 32-oz. (907 g) cans of tomato sauce, 2 cups (473 ml) of chicken broth, 2 tablespoons (15 g) of chicken bouillon powder, and 1 teaspoon (6 g) salt. Use a wooden spoon to mix all of the ingredients together so they’re fully combined. If you don’t have fresh garlic, you can substitute ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic powder.

steps.headline: Cook the sauce for several hours in the slow cooker.
steps.description: When all of the ingredients are mixed in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low. Allow the sauce to cook for 8 hours. If you want the sauce to be ready more quickly, cook it on high for 4 to 5 hours. Stir the sauce periodically as it’s cooking to ensure that all of the flavors are melding.

steps.headline: Strain the sauce.
steps.description: Once the sauce is finished cooking, pour it through a colander that’s set over a bowl to strain it. Remove the onion, jalapenos, and garlic cloves, and discard them.

steps.headline: Stir in the cilantro.
steps.description: After you’ve strained the sauce, add 2 tablespoons (6 g) of fresh, chopped cilantro. Mix it in well so it’s fully incorporated into the sauce. Adding the cilantro is an optional step. If you aren’t a fan of the flavor, you can omit it.

steps.headline: Use the sauce or freeze it for later.
steps.description: Once you’ve mixed in the cilantro, the sauce is ready to use with your favorite enchilada recipe. You’ll have enough for 2 9-inch by 13-inch (23-cm by 33-cm) baking dishes of enchiladas, so you may want to freeze half of it. To freeze the sauce, place it in an airtight container and store in the freezer for up to 3 months. The sauce will last approximately 4 days in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

methods.name: Whipping Up Slow Cooker Ancho Chili Enchilada Sauce

steps.headline: Whisk the cornstarch and water together.
steps.description: Add 3 tablespoons (24 g) of cornstarch and 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of water to a small bowl. Use a whisk to blend the two together into a smooth paste. You can substitute flour if you don’t have any cornstarch. However, you’ll want to cook the sauce for an extra 10 to 15 minutes to ensure that the raw flour taste is cooked out of it.

steps.headline: Combine all of the ingredients in the slow cooker.
steps.description: Once the cornstarch paste is mixed, add it to the slow cooker along with 2 cups (473 ml) of chicken broth, 1 8-oz. (227 g) can of roasted garlic tomato sauce, 2 tablespoons (16 g) of chili powder, 2 tablespoons (16 g) of ancho chili powder, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of cumin, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of garlic powder, ½ teaspoon (½ g) of dried oregano, and ½ teaspoon (3 g) of salt. Use a wooden spoon to blend all of the ingredients together. If you can’t find roasted garlic tomato sauce, you can substitute regular tomato sauce. You may want to add an extra ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic powder, though.

steps.headline: Cook the sauce for several hours.
steps.description: When all of the ingredients are combined in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low. Allow the sauce to cook for 4 to 6 hours, or until the sauce has reached your desired thickness. If you want the sauce to be ready more quickly, cook it on high for 2 to 3 hours.

steps.headline: Use the sauce in your enchilada recipe.
steps.description: Once the sauce is finished cooking, it’s ready to use for your favorite type of enchiladas. You can also allow the sauce to cool and place it in airtight plastic zipper bags or containers for storage. The sauce will last for 3 days in the refrigerator and up to 6 months in the freezer.

methods.name: Mixing Up Spicy Slow Cooker Chipotle Enchilada Sauce

steps.headline: Slice the chipotle peppers and remove the seeds.
steps.description: Open a can of chipotle peppers in adobo sauce. Remove 4 peppers from the can, and use a sharp knife to slice them open. Scrape out the seeds and discard them. Save the adobo sauce that’s left in the can. You’ll need some of it to mix into the sauce.

steps.headline: Mix all of the ingredients in the slow cooker.
steps.description: Add the chipotle peppers to the slow cooker along with 16 ounces (473) of chicken broth, 1 32-oz (907 g) can of fire roasted tomatoes, 2 diced onions, 5 garlic cloves, 2 tablespoons (30 g) of adobo sauce from the can of peppers, 1 ½ tablespoons (11 ½ g) of cumin, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of chili powder, 1 teaspoon (6 g) of salt, and a pinch of sugar. Stir all of the ingredients together so they’re well blended. This sauce is fairly spicy. If you want a milder version, add less chipotle peppers and adobo sauce to lessen the heat.

steps.headline: Cook the sauce for several hours.
steps.description: When all of the ingredients are mixed in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low. Allow the sauce to cook for 6 to 8 hours. You can cook the sauce on high for 3 to 4 hours if you want it to be ready more quickly.

steps.headline: Remove the chipotle peppers and puree the sauce.
steps.description: Once the sauce has finished cooking, use a spoon to lift out the chipotle peppers. With an immersion blender, puree the sauce until it is smooth. If you don’t have an immersion blender, you can transfer the sauce to a countertop blender to puree it.

steps.headline: Transfer the sauce to glass jars for storage.
steps.description: You can use the enchilada sauce right away. However, if you want to store it for use later, pour it into a glass jar. Allow it to cool, and keep in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks. You can also freeze the sauce if you aren’t going to use it in the immediate future. Allow it to cool, and then ladle it into freezer bags. Squeeze the excess air out, and lay the bags flat in the freezer for storage. Allow the sauce to thaw for 24 hours before warming up on the stove.

text: Preparing Basic Slow Cooker Enchilada Sauce Cut the onions and remove the skins. Use a sharp knife to cut 2 large onions in half. Use your fingers to peel away the skin, and set the onion pieces aside. Yellow onions work best for the enchilada sauce. Slice the jalapenos and remove the seeds. Cut 4 jalapenos in half with a sharp knife. Use a spoon to carefully scrape out the seeds and discard them. Wash your hands immediately after handling the jalapenos. The capsaicin in the jalapenos can sting your eyes if you touch them without washing your hands. Some people experience burning in their skin after handling jalapenos, so you may prefer to wear protective gloves, such as latex or rubber, while you’re cutting them. Mix all of the ingredients in the slow cooker. Once the onion and jalapenos are cut, place them in the slow cooker along with 4 cloves of garlic that have been peeled and smashed, ½ cup (64 g) of chili powder, 3 tablespoons (23 g) of cumin, 2 tablespoons (25 g) of sugar, 2 32-oz. (907 g) cans of tomato sauce, 2 cups (473 ml) of chicken broth, 2 tablespoons (15 g) of chicken bouillon powder, and 1 teaspoon (6 g) salt. Use a wooden spoon to mix all of the ingredients together so they’re fully combined. If you don’t have fresh garlic, you can substitute ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic powder. Cook the sauce for several hours in the slow cooker. When all of the ingredients are mixed in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low. Allow the sauce to cook for 8 hours. If you want the sauce to be ready more quickly, cook it on high for 4 to 5 hours. Stir the sauce periodically as it’s cooking to ensure that all of the flavors are melding. Strain the sauce. Once the sauce is finished cooking, pour it through a colander that’s set over a bowl to strain it. Remove the onion, jalapenos, and garlic cloves, and discard them. Stir in the cilantro. After you’ve strained the sauce, add 2 tablespoons (6 g) of fresh, chopped cilantro. Mix it in well so it’s fully incorporated into the sauce. Adding the cilantro is an optional step. If you aren’t a fan of the flavor, you can omit it. Use the sauce or freeze it for later. Once you’ve mixed in the cilantro, the sauce is ready to use with your favorite enchilada recipe. You’ll have enough for 2 9-inch by 13-inch (23-cm by 33-cm) baking dishes of enchiladas, so you may want to freeze half of it. To freeze the sauce, place it in an airtight container and store in the freezer for up to 3 months. The sauce will last approximately 4 days in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Whipping Up Slow Cooker Ancho Chili Enchilada Sauce Whisk the cornstarch and water together. Add 3 tablespoons (24 g) of cornstarch and 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of water to a small bowl. Use a whisk to blend the two together into a smooth paste. You can substitute flour if you don’t have any cornstarch. However, you’ll want to cook the sauce for an extra 10 to 15 minutes to ensure that the raw flour taste is cooked out of it. Combine all of the ingredients in the slow cooker. Once the cornstarch paste is mixed, add it to the slow cooker along with 2 cups (473 ml) of chicken broth, 1 8-oz. (227 g) can of roasted garlic tomato sauce, 2 tablespoons (16 g) of chili powder, 2 tablespoons (16 g) of ancho chili powder, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of cumin, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of garlic powder, ½ teaspoon (½ g) of dried oregano, and ½ teaspoon (3 g) of salt. Use a wooden spoon to blend all of the ingredients together. If you can’t find roasted garlic tomato sauce, you can substitute regular tomato sauce. You may want to add an extra ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic powder, though. Cook the sauce for several hours. When all of the ingredients are combined in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low. Allow the sauce to cook for 4 to 6 hours, or until the sauce has reached your desired thickness. If you want the sauce to be ready more quickly, cook it on high for 2 to 3 hours. Use the sauce in your enchilada recipe. Once the sauce is finished cooking, it’s ready to use for your favorite type of enchiladas. You can also allow the sauce to cool and place it in airtight plastic zipper bags or containers for storage. The sauce will last for 3 days in the refrigerator and up to 6 months in the freezer. Mixing Up Spicy Slow Cooker Chipotle Enchilada Sauce Slice the chipotle peppers and remove the seeds. Open a can of chipotle peppers in adobo sauce. Remove 4 peppers from the can, and use a sharp knife to slice them open. Scrape out the seeds and discard them. Save the adobo sauce that’s left in the can. You’ll need some of it to mix into the sauce. Mix all of the ingredients in the slow cooker. Add the chipotle peppers to the slow cooker along with 16 ounces (473) of chicken broth, 1 32-oz (907 g) can of fire roasted tomatoes, 2 diced onions, 5 garlic cloves, 2 tablespoons (30 g) of adobo sauce from the can of peppers, 1 ½ tablespoons (11 ½ g) of cumin, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of chili powder, 1 teaspoon (6 g) of salt, and a pinch of sugar. Stir all of the ingredients together so they’re well blended. This sauce is fairly spicy. If you want a milder version, add less chipotle peppers and adobo sauce to lessen the heat. Cook the sauce for several hours. When all of the ingredients are mixed in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low. Allow the sauce to cook for 6 to 8 hours. You can cook the sauce on high for 3 to 4 hours if you want it to be ready more quickly. Remove the chipotle peppers and puree the sauce. Once the sauce has finished cooking, use a spoon to lift out the chipotle peppers. With an immersion blender, puree the sauce until it is smooth. If you don’t have an immersion blender, you can transfer the sauce to a countertop blender to puree it. Transfer the sauce to glass jars for storage. You can use the enchilada sauce right away. However, if you want to store it for use later, pour it into a glass jar. Allow it to cool, and keep in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks. You can also freeze the sauce if you aren’t going to use it in the immediate future. Allow it to cool, and then ladle it into freezer bags. Squeeze the excess air out, and lay the bags flat in the freezer for storage. Allow the sauce to thaw for 24 hours before warming up on the stove. Finished.
sentences: Preparing Basic Slow Cooker Enchilada Sauce Cut the onions and remove the skins.
Use a sharp knife to cut 2 large onions in half.
Use your fingers to peel away the skin, and set the onion pieces aside.
Yellow onions work best for the enchilada sauce.
Slice the jalapenos and remove the seeds.
Cut 4 jalapenos in half with a sharp knife.
Use a spoon to carefully scrape out the seeds and discard them.
Wash your hands immediately after handling the jalapenos.
The capsaicin in the jalapenos can sting your eyes if you touch them without washing your hands.
Some people experience burning in their skin after handling jalapenos, so you may prefer to wear protective gloves, such as latex or rubber, while you’re cutting them.
Mix all of the ingredients in the slow cooker.

Once the onion and jalapenos are cut, place them in the slow cooker along with 4 cloves of garlic that have been peeled and smashed, ½ cup (64 g) of chili powder, 3 tablespoons (23 g) of cumin, 2 tablespoons (25 g) of sugar, 2 32-oz.
(907 g) cans of tomato sauce, 2 cups (473 ml) of chicken broth, 2 tablespoons (15 g) of chicken bouillon powder, and 1 teaspoon (6 g) salt.
Use a wooden spoon to mix all of the ingredients together so they’re fully combined.
If you don’t have fresh garlic, you can substitute ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic powder.
Cook the sauce for several hours in the slow cooker.
When all of the ingredients are mixed in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low.
Allow the sauce to cook for 8 hours.
If you want the sauce to be ready more quickly, cook it on high for 4 to 5 hours.
Stir the sauce periodically as it’s cooking to ensure that all of the flavors are melding.
Strain the sauce.
Once the sauce is finished cooking, pour it through a colander that’s set over a bowl to strain it.
Remove the onion, jalapenos, and garlic cloves, and discard them.
Stir in the cilantro.
After you’ve strained the sauce, add 2 tablespoons (6 g) of fresh, chopped cilantro.
Mix it in well so it’s fully incorporated into the sauce.
Adding the cilantro is an optional step.
If you aren’t a fan of the flavor, you can omit it.
Use the sauce or freeze it for later.
Once you’ve mixed in the cilantro, the sauce is ready to use with your favorite enchilada recipe.
You’ll have enough for 2 9-inch by 13-inch (23-cm by 33-cm) baking dishes of enchiladas, so you may want to freeze half of it.
To freeze the sauce, place it in an airtight container and store in the freezer for up to 3 months.
The sauce will last approximately 4 days in an airtight container in the refrigerator.
Whipping Up Slow Cooker Ancho Chili Enchilada Sauce Whisk the cornstarch and water together.
Add 3 tablespoons (24 g) of cornstarch and 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of water to a small bowl.
Use a whisk to blend the two together into a smooth paste.
You can substitute flour if you don’t have any cornstarch.
However, you’ll want to cook the sauce for an extra 10 to 15 minutes to ensure that the raw flour taste is cooked out of it.
Combine all of the ingredients in the slow cooker.
Once the cornstarch paste is mixed, add it to the slow cooker along with 2 cups (473 ml) of chicken broth, 1 8-oz.

(227 g) can of roasted garlic tomato sauce, 2 tablespoons (16 g) of chili powder, 2 tablespoons (16 g) of ancho chili powder, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of cumin, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of garlic powder, ½ teaspoon (½ g) of dried oregano, and ½ teaspoon (3 g) of salt.
Use a wooden spoon to blend all of the ingredients together.
If you can’t find roasted garlic tomato sauce, you can substitute regular tomato sauce.
You may want to add an extra ½ teaspoon (1 ½ g) of garlic powder, though.
Cook the sauce for several hours.
When all of the ingredients are combined in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low.
Allow the sauce to cook for 4 to 6 hours, or until the sauce has reached your desired thickness.
If you want the sauce to be ready more quickly, cook it on high for 2 to 3 hours.
Use the sauce in your enchilada recipe.
Once the sauce is finished cooking, it’s ready to use for your favorite type of enchiladas.
You can also allow the sauce to cool and place it in airtight plastic zipper bags or containers for storage.
The sauce will last for 3 days in the refrigerator and up to 6 months in the freezer.
Mixing Up Spicy Slow Cooker Chipotle Enchilada Sauce Slice the chipotle peppers and remove the seeds.
Open a can of chipotle peppers in adobo sauce.
Remove 4 peppers from the can, and use a sharp knife to slice them open.
Scrape out the seeds and discard them.
Save the adobo sauce that’s left in the can.
You’ll need some of it to mix into the sauce.
Mix all of the ingredients in the slow cooker.

Add the chipotle peppers to the slow cooker along with 16 ounces (473) of chicken broth, 1 32-oz (907 g) can of fire roasted tomatoes, 2 diced onions, 5 garlic cloves, 2 tablespoons (30 g) of adobo sauce from the can of peppers, 1 ½ tablespoons (11 ½ g) of cumin, 1 teaspoon (3 g) of chili powder, 1 teaspoon (6 g) of salt, and a pinch of sugar.
Stir all of the ingredients together so they’re well blended.
This sauce is fairly spicy.
If you want a milder version, add less chipotle peppers and adobo sauce to lessen the heat.
Cook the sauce for several hours.
When all of the ingredients are mixed in the slow cooker, turn it on and set it to low.
Allow the sauce to cook for 6 to 8 hours.
You can cook the sauce on high for 3 to 4 hours if you want it to be ready more quickly.
Remove the chipotle peppers and puree the sauce.
Once the sauce has finished cooking, use a spoon to lift out the chipotle peppers.
With an immersion blender, puree the sauce until it is smooth.
If you don’t have an immersion blender, you can transfer the sauce to a countertop blender to puree it.
Transfer the sauce to glass jars for storage.
You can use the enchilada sauce right away.
However, if you want to store it for use later, pour it into a glass jar.
Allow it to cool, and keep in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.
You can also freeze the sauce if you aren’t going to use it in the immediate future.
Allow it to cool, and then ladle it into freezer bags.
Squeeze the excess air out, and lay the bags flat in the freezer for storage.
Allow the sauce to thaw for 24 hours before warming up on the stove.
Finished.
